Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Cutting Tool Wear Monitoring Sensor
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader/commercial impact of this I-Corps project involves exploring the commercial potential of cutting tool wear monitoring sensors. Cutting tool manufacturers, machine tool manufacturers, and CNC machine operating companies can potentially benefit through improved cutting tool production processes and saving tooling time needed for production. There is a potential growing industrial customer need to accurately, precisely, and inexpensively sense and diagnose cutting tool wear, damage, and/or cutting edge quality. However, there are few reliable instruments available in the market with the required accuracy, resolution, cost, and on-machine usage. The proposed sensor allows for high-resolution monitoring and diagnosis of edge quality by providing quantitative information on morphological properties, including tool edge quality and wear related to abrasion, attrition, and chipping.

This I-Corps project bridges a knowledge gap existing between the state-of-the-art instrumentation technologies and cutting tool inspection methods. Existing methods do not typically provide a quantitative measure to monitor the health of precision cutting tools in a convenient and time/cost-effective manner. The knife-edge interferometer developed in this project allows for precision cutting tool wear measurement and monitoring by providing quantitative information on morphological properties including abrasion, attrition, and chipping. This project enables a new cutting tool wear monitoring paradigm, producing new knowledge in instrumentation and characterization. This research will create a new transformative wear diagnosis principle for precision cutting tools to improve manufacturing reliability and the automation process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of the project is to identify customer segment and value proposition of new knowledge in cutting tool inspection and its instrumentation technology and intellectual properties (IP) gained through the PI’s previous NSF-funded projects (CMMI #1564254) by engaging with industry personnel. The team consisted of EL (graduate student), co-EL (undergraduate student), IM and TL interviewed many industry personnel to test the thesis that cutting tool manufacturers, machine tool manufacturers, and CNC (computer numeric control) machine tool operating companies will find value in a time and cost effective sensor that better enables the cutting tool production process to support production. The team conducted 135 interviews (111 in-person, 11 video calls, and 13 phone calls). The value proposition, customer segment, and business category for cutting tool monitoring sensors toward commercialization were detailed. The results showed that hardware, software, and maintenance services for cutting tool quality control are potentially attractive to cutting tool manufacturers and users. For example, because tooling cost takes approximately 3% of total manufacturing costs in most automotive manufacturing industry, many customer segments are looking forward to solutions for innovation of tooling cost reduction and low-cost product quality control. However, based on an assessment of the overall customer development obtained through this project, a ‘No-go’ decision was made. It was because the focus of many engineers in manufacturing industry is not on the cutting tools, but on the machine tools although the cutting tool quality directly influences the overall quality of manufacturing and production. Although all engineers, managers, and directors interviewed through the I-Corps project accepted the importance and potential of cutting tool quality monitoring to deliver changes in cutting tool manufacturing processes, there is no specific demand for cutting tool quality and diagnosis because such technology has not been introduced to the industry. Compiling data on the needs and expectations collected through the I-Corps project, the team has narrowed down the customer segments and has been looking for the market, developing the cutting tool monitoring sensor technology toward commercialization.

The PI and his team have an understanding of the market needs related to cutting tool quality control and diagnosis technology. As part of the I-Corps project, the team finalized value propositions of the proposed technology and target customers, developed sensor specifications based on customer needs, and formulated strategic plans for the next phase towards commercialization. The proposed commercialization project will significantly improve production quality and manufacturing efficiency of cutting tools, creating a new transformative quality control and diagnosis principle for cutting tools to enhance manufacturing reliability and automation process by combining measurement technology with Information and Communication Technology (ICT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology. It will also answer fundamental questions regarding the performance boundaries of the proposed technology and on-machine/in-process measurement technologies for cutting tool quality control and diagnosis, and can be used to investigate the cutting tool wear and fracture mechanisms. The proposed research can potentially transform the design of precision instruments for sensing or manufacturing process automation. As previously demonstrated, one potential application is dimensional sensing for machine tools that require high speed, precision, and repeatability in either on-machine or in-process configurations. Therefore, this technology can be implemented in manufacturing processes in the automotive industry, cutting tool manufacturing industry, and CNC machine tools industry. In addition, successful execution of the proposed research will potentially lead to a fundamental shift in structural health monitoring of precision cutting tools by providing quantitative information about the morphological properties and remaining service life of the cutting tools. In addition, this research will potentially lead to widespread adoption of a new methodology for the sensing, monitoring, and inspection of a variety of edge surfaces in atomic force microscopy and touch-triggered stylus probes, grinding wheels, and milling tools. 

Because this field of study is inherently interdisciplinary in nature, expertise across traditional disciplinary boundaries with comprehensive coverage of various disciplines is necessary. This field of study is of great interest not only to academia and national laboratories, but also to a wide range of industrial sectors. To avoid the pitfalls of falling behind the ever-changing needs of academia and industry, two ELs were trained to have knowledge and entrepreneurship toward commercialization with cutting-edge precision manufacturing technology.

 


Last Modified: 04/14/2020
Modified by: Chabum Lee
